more_info.origin: Natural colour isolated from the roots and stem of Yellowroot (Curcuma longa  and Curcuma domestica). Turmeric is the crude extract, whereas curcumin is the purified compound. It imparts the yellow colour to curry powder. More on curcumin, click .
more_info.characteristics: Food colour, whose colour ranges from yellow to red, depending on pH (acidity). It is not very soluble in water.
more_info.daily_intake: Up to 1 mg/kg body weight for curcumin, and 0.3 mg/kg for turmeric.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E100 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour isolated from the roots and stem of Yellowroot (Curcuma longa  and Curcuma domestica). Turmeric is the crude extract, whereas curcumin is the purified compound. It imparts the yellow colour to curry powder. More on curcumin, click .
more_info.characteristics: Food colour, whose colour ranges from yellow to red, depending on pH (acidity). It is not very soluble in water.
more_info.daily_intake: Up to 1 mg/kg body weight for curcumin, and 0.3 mg/kg for turmeric.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E100 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour present in many foods such as milk, eggs, liver and vegetables. Commercially prepared from yeasts. It is also manufactured synthetically.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Not very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E101 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians. Although it can be produced from milk, this is not done commercially.

more_info.origin: Natural colour present in many foods such as milk, eggs, liver and vegetables. Commercially prepared from yeasts. It is also manufactured synthetically.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Not very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E101 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians. Although it can be produced from milk, this is not done commercially.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Tartrazine is an azo dye. No side effects are known for pure tartrazine, except in people who are intolerant to salicylates (aspirin, berries, fruits); in that case tartrazine also induces intolerance symptoms. In combination with benzoates (E210-215), tartrazine is implicated in a large percentage of cases of ADHD syndrome (hyperactivity) in children. Asthmatics may also experience symptoms following consumption of tartrazine, as it is a known histamine-liberating agent.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E102 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic non-azo dye.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: There are no side effects known in the concentrations used, although E104 may act as a histamine liberator.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E104 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour present in many foods such as milk, eggs, liver and vegetables. Commercially prepared from yeasts. It is also manufactured synthetically.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Not very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E101 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians. Although it can be produced from milk, this is not done commercially.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, E107 is implicated in allergies, hyperactivity and asthma. Use is limited and the colour may be banned in the near future.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E107 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Yellow food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E110 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural red food colour isolated from the insects     Dactylopius coccus, living on different species of succulents. E120(i) is the pure colour, whereas E120(ii) is the crude extract. For more information, see the background file on .
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects in the concentrations used in foods. Increased hyperactivity has been reported in a few cases. Contact allergy is well known when used in cosmetics.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: As it is extracted from insects, E120 cannot be consumed by vegans and vegetarians and neither by some religious groups.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E122 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children. A connection between tumours and amaranth has been established in rats, but not (un)proven in humans. Nevertheless, many countries have restricted the use pending further tests, and the ADI has been reduced to 0.5 mg/kg.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E123 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E124 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic iodine-containing red dye.
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Few side effects in the concentrations used in foods. Increased hyperactivity has been reported in a few cases, as well as a possible connection with mutagenicity. Erythrosine causes an increased photosensitivity in people with sensitivity to sunlight. In high concentrations erythrosine interferes with iodine metabolism. However, these concentrations cannot be reached through the consumption of food.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E127 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye.
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.products: Restricted use in confectionery and meat products.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children. Furthermore, Red 2G may well bring about anaemia and it is possibly mutagenic. Consequently, its use has been very much restricted and the ADI reduced.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E128 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Red food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.products: Restricted use in confectionery and meat products.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children. One of its degradation products causes bladder cancer in animals when present in high concentrations.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E129 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic blue colour.
more_info.characteristics: Blue food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Side effects rarely occur in the concentrations used in foods. Rare allergic reactions have been described, due to coupling of the colour to (body) proteins. It can also function as a histamine liberator.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E131 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Blue colour, naturally present in the shrub Indigofera tinctoria , though commercially it is produced synthetically.
more_info.characteristics: Blue food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Side effects rarely occur in the concentrations used in foods. Rare allergic reactions have been described, due to coupling of the colour to (body) proteins. It can also function as a histamine liberator.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E132 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic blue colour.
more_info.characteristics: Blue food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.products: Ice cream and a few other food products, but mostly in cosmetics.
more_info.side_effects: Side effects rarely occur in the concentrations used. Some allergic reactions have been reported.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E133 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural green colour, present in all plants and algae. Commercially extracted from nettles, grass and alfalfa.
more_info.characteristics: Green, water-soluble food colour.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects are known.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E140 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.characteristics: Green food colour. E141 (i) is soluble in water, whereas E141 (ii) is soluble in oil.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects are known. Copper is released when E141 is heated; however, copper concentrations from this compound will not reach toxic levels.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E141 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.characteristics: Green food colour. E142 is soluble in water, but unstable in acid or alkaline solutions.
more_info.side_effects: Very few side effects are known. In some cases allergies or anaemia have been reported.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E142 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.characteristics: Brown to black colours. Soluble in water and with a specific, sometimes bitter, taste.
more_info.daily_intake: Up to 200 mg/kg body weight for E150c and E150d, whereas there is no ADI for E150a and/or E150b.
more_info.side_effects: Side effects are manifested from the use of E150c and E150d, where intestinal problems may occur after ingestion of large amounts. Due to the complex nature of the mixtures, toxicology tests are still being carried out.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E150 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Synthetic azo dye. See  for a background on azo dyes.
more_info.characteristics: Black food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.products: Restricted use, but in large product range.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children. In the intestines, it can be transformed by bacteria into possibly hazardous compounds, hence the rather low ADI and restricted use.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E151 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.characteristics: Brown food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children. Some of the compounds in the mixture may be mutagenic; hence the use is restricted to a few products.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E154 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.characteristics: Brown food colour. Very soluble in water.
more_info.products: Restricted use in confectionery and bakery products.
more_info.side_effects: Since it is an azo dye, it may elicit intolerance in people intolerant to salicylates. Additionally, it is a histamine liberator, and may intensify symptoms of asthma. In combination with benzoates, it is also implicated in hyperactivity in children.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E155 can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour isolated from several plants; however, it is obtained commercially from carrots. Carotenes occur as isomers, consisting of a series of chemically identical, but sterically different components. The actual composition differs between the plant species.
more_info.characteristics: Water-insoluble food colour whose colour ranges from yellow to orange, depending on the solvent used for extraction.
more_info.daily_intake: Up to 5 mg/kg body weight for E160a (i), whereas none has been determined for the other compounds.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods. High concentrations will result in yellow discoloration of the skin. As carotene is a source of vitamin A (2 parts of carotene equal 1 part of vitamin A), high concentrations will cause symptoms of vitamin A toxicity.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E160a can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour isolated from the seeds of the  tree (Bixa orellana ). Annatto is the name of the crude extract, whereas bixin is the fat-soluble colour and norbixin the water-soluble colour.
more_info.characteristics: Food colour whose colour ranges from red to brown depending on the solvent used for extraction.
more_info.daily_intake: Up to 2.5 mg/kg body weight for annatto, and 0.065 mg/kg body weight for bixin.
more_info.side_effects: Annatto can cause allergies and eczema. It is not always known which component in the mixture is the causative agent of the side effects.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E160b can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour isolated from the bell pepper, Capsicum annuum . This mixture mainly contains capsacain and capsorubin.
more_info.side_effects: None known
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E160c can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many yellow and red plants and fruits. Commercially isolated from tomatoes. See also the background file on .
more_info.side_effects: None known.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E160d can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. It is made commercially from carotene or isolated from plants.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known in the concentrations used in foods. High concentrations will result in yellow discoloration of the skin. As E160e is a source of vitamin A, high concentrations will cause symptoms of vitamin A toxicity.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E160e can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. It is made commercially from E160e or isolated from plants.
more_info.side_effects: No side effects known.
more_info.dietary_restrictions: None; E160f can be consumed by all religious groups, vegans and vegetarians.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. Commercially prepared from buttercup (Ranunculus sp. ).
more_info.products: Rarely used. If used only in confectionary.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. Commercially prepared from grass, nettles or Tagetes  species.
more_info.products: Rarely used. If used only in soups and alcoholic beverages.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. Commercially prepared from Physalis  species.
more_info.products: Rarely used. If used only in confectionary.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. Commercially prepared from Rosa  (rose) species.
Natural colour, present in many plants. Commercially prepared from Viola  species.
Natural colour, present in many plants and birds. Commercially prepared from different plant species.
Natural colour, present in many plants and birds. Commercially prepared from catharelles (mushroom) or flamingo feathers. However, it is mainly produced synthetically from carotene.
more_info.products: Widely used, also in tanning pills.

more_info.origin: Natural colour, present in many plants. Commercially prepared from several dried plants species.
Natural colour commercially prepared from beetroot. More details on the colour, see .
more_info.products: Widely used, but the colour is rather unstable.

more_info.origin: Anthocyanins and anthocyanidins are a large group of natural colours. The colour of most fruits, flowers and berries is made up from a combination of anthocyanins and anthocyanidins. Anthocyanins always contain a carbohydrate molecule, whereas anthocyanidins lack this molecule. The individual compounds are isolated from different plant species. E163(i)-(iii) are mixtures. More on anthocyanins and structure, see .
more_info.products: Widely used, but the colours are rather unstable. Temperature, light and pH can influence the colour.
more_info.daily_intake: None determined except for E163(ii) : up to 2.5 mg/kg body weight

more_info.origin: Natural white mineral.
Natural white mineral.
Natural minerals, but commercially made from iron powder.
Natural metal.
Natural metal.
Natural metal.
Synthetic azo-colour, contains aluminium and calcium ions. See  for a background on azo dyes.
Natural mixture with complex composition. Commercially prepared from acorns or prepared synthetically.
